B8DF9A13D11448B4BD567C31FCC922B7.description: Acquire new skills and demonstrate a determination to develop those skills.
comments: Example: Demonstrate active engagement in the physical education lesson; student actively participates with little or no prompting from the teacher.

F4A422E37ED241BD8A400821B40F573D.description: Discuss personal opinions about participation in physical activity.
comments: Example: Express verbal feedback of an activity to the teacher (e.g., teacher evaluates a lesson by informally asking students their opinion of a game/activity and observes if participation was active or passive).

4647F38251EE4D3D977004E74C7C08A4.description: Express enjoyment and self-confidence when participating in movement experiences.
comments: Example: Demonstrate active participation in a child-centered lesson for learning new skills (e.g., teacher plans developmentally appropriate lessons to minimize the effect of initial failures: physical fitness activities/games that do not eliminate students, use of balloons for striking with a racquet or paddle, use lightweight balls for bouncing).

9742945E80B64F4FB9F97CB295257E0B.description: Value of Physical Activity: Students value physical activity for health, enjoyment, challenge, self-expression, and/or social interaction.

0D2779289E864323AFFBD46C15E98027.description: Demonstrate respect for other children in physical education class.
comments: Example: Practice a skill with the person or group to which one is assigned.

C47476FA6939477B8B75243D54C3FFD7.description: Show a positive attitude toward self and others during physical activity.
comments: Example: Exercise alone and exercise with other children in which differences exist (e.g., ability, race, gender, and socioeconomic status).

01532FCF6E3B4620B1107C54CCD3A8E4.description: Exhibit a willingness to follow basic directions for an active class.
comments: Example: Respond to teacher's signals for start and stop, verbal cues, directions, and visual demonstrations.

E0FEFC5903FB4E61BFD51248265F7076.description: Identify and demonstrate an understanding of rules and safety practices for games and other physical activities
comments: Example: Exhibit successful participation in activities/games with boundary lines (e.g., cones and lines indicate activity parameters) and understand rules for safe active play (e.g., awareness of personal space).

0E33DBD3C7CB4CC1B3A807052B89991B.description: Responsible Personal and Social Behavior: Students exhibit responsible personal and social behavior that respects self and others in physical activity settings.

C3041302F95B416D8C34D94DD3C526CE.description: Identify the basic effects of physical activity on heart and lung function.
comments: Example: Observe and feel fast heart and breathing rates when engaged in skill development and physical fitness activities (e.g., feel a slow heart rate and observe a slow breathing rate before skill and fitness stations begin, after ten or more minutes feel and observe fast heart and breathing rates).

A0D2AA9350A746E1AADDA1FEA1056FC8.description: Demonstrate improved flexibility in three different joints.
comments: Example: Demonstrate engagement in specific stretches to improve lower back flexion (e.g., seated and standing straddle stretches, seal stretch).

502DC087DEDC422981404B9D80DCAEDB.description: Demonstrate improved muscular strength and endurance.
comments: Example: Improve upper body and abdominal strength by engaging in specific exercises throughout the school year (e.g., shoulder touches, modified push-ups, v-sit, modified crunch).

Example: Engage in vigorous activity, progressing from short periods to longer periods of time (e.g., chasing and fleeing physical fitness activity/game, skill development activity, walk/run at one's individual pace at an outdoor fitness trail; playground fitness stations).

6A5DB0C588764F6D82FB5AEE60A492D2.description: Health-Enhancing Physical Fitness: Students achieve and maintain a health-enhancing level of physical fitness.

813CBBB039894C4693A433ACF9351F80.description: Display enjoyment in participation in moderate to vigorous physical activity in physical education class and in after school time.
comments: Example: Express enthusiasm and enjoyment while being physically active (e.g., choose favorite games to play; willingly participate in learning new movement skills; choose to be active at recess).

4B04E25D74DC42DF8BBFCE587CC2DC40.description: Show skills and knowledge acquired in physical education class during after school physical activities.
comments: Example: Demonstrate willing participation in active play at recess, in unstructured play with friends and family, or in community recreation/sport leagues (e.g., teacher initiates conversation with students for informal assessment of after school physical activity participation).

7D2617693BD348DC92059328EA13A402.description: Physical Activity: Students participate regularly in physical activity.

3B9FFD05932F4B878B42A59DE47FC4EC.description: Identify and demonstrate basic principles for learning basic movement skills.
comments: Example: Verbally identify and practice the basic principles for balance (e.g., arms extended for walking on a balance board), basic footwork skills (e.g., soccer ball dribble with soft taps of feet), and catching a ball (e.g., reach out with hands).

DDA8451305CC40F988D8CB93714694D5.description: Demonstrate variations in moving with spatial, directional, and temporal awareness.
comments: Example: Move in various directions (forward, backward, sideward), at various levels (high, low), in various patterns (straight, curved), and at various speeds (fast, slow) in skill development activities (e.g., walk on a curved rope on the floor; stretch high, low level for a crab walk; run fast in a tag game).

C9B21200F05742EB8B787BC24CF4618B.description: Demonstrate basic (fundamental) movement vocabulary and cue words for learning skills.
comments: Example: Recognize movements and cues (e.g., gallop cue: leader leg; forward roll cue: be small and roll like a ball; kick a ball cue: toe down).

D4B6085E95EF46079913A68A5FCC1DE0.description: Movement Concepts: Students demonstrate an understanding of movement concepts, principles, strategies, and tactics as they apply to the learning and performance of physical activities.

D5C43DA02A5E497E953EDEDBF5D53E5D.description: Perform basic movements in a rhythmic manner.
comments: Example: Perform locomotor skills to a specific rhythm (e.g., walk to the rhythm as the teacher gives/calls directions for a simple circle dance; walk to drum beat; jump over a stationary rope on the floor while counting in a rhythm).
Example: Demonstrate eye-hand and eye-foot coordination skills (e.g., throw a ball above head, hit a balloon with hands, strike a balloon with a racquet, bounce a ball, kick a stationary ball).

Example: Demonstrate balance on stable and unstable objects (e.g., walk on a rope on the floor, a balance board, on top of tires) and/or demonstrate weight transfer/tumbling skills (e.g., log roll, egg roll, forward roll).

Example: Demonstrate walk, run, leap, jump, hop, gallop, slide, and skip in skill development practice/activities (e.g., run when you hear the color of your eyes; jump over a line on the floor; leap over a pillow).

F3D59DA2C99042AFB69ACE4BF624B4A9.description: Motor Skills and Movement Patterns: Students demonstrate competency in motor skills and movement patterns needed to perform a variety of physical activities.

BDCA655496D443109FD4F9A2CEDA6996.description: With guidance and support from adults, recall information from experiences or gather information from provided sources to answer a question.

39CB7A8D6F3E43CD937AF2A0577F9216.description: Participate in shared research and writing projects (e.g., explore a number of books by a favorite author and express opinions about them) (This standard not required in PE).

F0262A3F5C644DF1A2F20B9C3D454BA4.description: Research to Build and Present Knowledge

E63DDED34D854C75A936355F6C5C24AB.description: With guidance and support from adults, explore a variety of digital tools to produce and publish writing, including collaboration with peers (This standard not required in PE).

9B930D4C30174454A2041E3B1589677E.description: With guidance and support from adults, respond to questions and suggestions from peers and add details to strengthen writing as needed (This standard not required in PE).

56ACC898F39E4B1596CF9CBCEC0E1388.description: Use a combination of drawing, dictating, and writing to narrate a single event or several loosely linked events, tell about the events in the order in which they occurred, and provide a reaction to what happened (This standard not required in PE).

76F8535EE07D408A9DFE353025794A26.description: Use a combination of drawing, dictating, and writing to compose informative/explanatory texts in which they name what they are writing about and supply some information about the topic.

C2B9E6B1F28946358C80A04E45552E2D.description: Use a combination of drawing, dictating, and writing to compose opinion pieces in which they tell a reader the topic or the name of the book they are writing about and state an opinion or preference about the topic or book (e.g., My favorite book isâ€¦) (This standard not required in PE).

comments: The following standards offer a focus for instruction to help ensure that students gain adequate mastery of a range of skills and applications. Each year in their writing, students should demonstrate increasing sophistication in all aspects of language use, from vocabulary and syntax to the development and organization of ideas, and they should address increasingly demanding content and sources. Students advancing through the grades are expected to meet each year's grade-specific standards and retain or further develop skills and understandings mastered in preceding grades.

69BDE36E362A4B2C821188E5D8009342.description: Actively engage in group reading activities with purpose and understanding (This standard not required in PE).

C24C1898C4EB46CC9C426F05E4C0BEDF.description: Range of Reading and Level of Text Complexity

F93E5F5F167F4EFF9E88A7F7BFA092E6.description: With prompting and support, identify basic similarities in and differences between two texts on the same topic (e.g., illustrations, descriptions, or procedures) (This standard not required in PE).

90C613F345894B56B93A1A337D51E51B.description: With prompting and support, identify the reasons an author gives to support points in a text.

EEBC92023DD64311B6F023AE0A342B94.description: With prompting and support, describe the relationship between illustrations and the text in which they appear (e.g., what person, place, thing, or idea in the text an illustration depicts).

9B201BAD30914883B8792F2FB6E4E197.description: Name the author and illustrator of a text and define the role of each in presenting the ideas or information in a text (This standard not required in PE).

535E3D3123DB44DB8700C508CF395BCB.description: Identify the front cover, back cover, and title page of a book (This standard not required in PE).

8E6A8C0958474AFEACC9B39486E51CED.description: With prompting and support, ask and answer questions about unknown words in a text related to PE.

5B3853FD919E458C910BF96C337782A6.description: With prompting and support, describe the connection between two individuals, events, ideas, or pieces of information in a text (This standard not required in PE).

32A91706FA104CCFA2A1A87861209491.description: With prompting and support, identify the main topic and retell key details of a text (This standard not required in PE).

4E138EB0588E45499C0DB7BF68049DC4.description: With prompting and support, ask and answer questions about key details in a text related to PE.

comments: The following standards offer a focus for instruction each year and help ensure that students gain adequate exposure to a range of texts and tasks. Rigor is also infused through the requirement that students read increasingly complex texts through the grades. Students advancing through the grades are expected to meet each year's grade-specific standards and retain or further develop skills and understandings mastered in preceding grades.
